1413.content:
Frustrated, Skander said, "You're s'posed to be my friend. I've had enough of crap this morning, I don't need this."

In the back of his mind, Skander felt the vibrations of Jase's voice again. "Here we go again...does he have to act so weak?"

"I'm not weak, damnit. I'm just going through hell right now, okay?"

Jase rose his brows. "How did you hear that?"

"What do you mean? I heard you, you called me weak."

"No," Jase said, "I thought it."

But Skander wasn't paying attention. His eyes were on his book.

Later that day:

When Skander walked into Geometry, he felt even worse. His head was pounding so hard he thought he might scream at the pain of it. He could hear so many voices; the girl he sat with at lunch kept telling him over and over again what "odi et amo" in Latin meant for her quiz next period; the boy near him in the bathroom stall was screaming curse words as he wrote them with Sharpies on the walls. They were everywhere, and he couldn't take it!

"Skander," Mrs. Woods said in her calm, sweet voice, "are you all right?"

He immediately nodded his head.

"You don't look well. Maybe you should see the nurse..."

So he left. Just like that. But he didn't see the nurse, he decided to go home instead. He massaged his temples, walking down the hallway. Behind him, he could hear the faint murmur of a boy's voice. It was low and threatening: "They won't know. They'll never know who it was. Oh, God, I can't wait...I can't wait this out, I can't. I have to do it, now! I have to blow up the school!"

Skander watched as the boy passed him, running down the hall. He was wearing a black hoodie that he pulled over his eyes. He looked furious.

Skander stood in horror...what was this boy going to do? How could he stop him?
1413.title: What next?

choices: The showdown
14131.content:
The boy was picking up speed. He descended the stairs two at a time. Again and again he thought about the face of old Mr. Graham, who scolded him every time he messed up in class. He hated that office secretary: Miss Payne. Why did she always give him attitude? Why did they have to be so cruel?

Skander tried to forget the pain in his head. The whole day, he had tried to make himself believe this wasn't real. But he couldn't fight it anymore. He swallowed the fear inside him. "I can read minds," he whispered. It was unbelievable, but he accepted it. Of all the things in his life that had affected him to this point, by far this was the greatest. He could hear if a cute girl thought about him, if he passed the class he thought he'd been failing in, if his parents were really in love and not putting on an act to ruin his life. It made people so much easier to trust...and he still could not believe how his "friend" had treated him. Was everyone like that? Friends in words but enemies in thoughts? Now he knew everything...and it was only the beginning.

"STOP!" Skander shouted.

The boy skidded to a halt. "Who are you and what the hell do you think you're doing here?"

"I on to you. You think you're the only one who knows?"

He furrowed his brow and waited for Skander to explain himself.

But Skander didn't do that; he pounced on him. The boy tossed Skander from his shoulders, cursing. Skander came back, this time with a punch. It hit the boy's cheek and his face curled around the fist. Skander stared at his hand in shock. He'd almost broken the boy's cheek bone under the strength in that single hit. He stood still, wondering if this was a good thing.

Fighting off the pain, the boy jumped the last step and ran for the gymnasium. No one had ever suspected this of him; why would they? He was only a baseball player. More like a bench-warmer, actually. They'd never guess that he'd keep this in his locker; he'd decide to kill everyone who had ever wronged him.

He kept a close watch on the class in there. They were caught up in a good game of dodgeball. One girl threw her body to the right, picked up a bright pink ball and tossed it at an enemy. The ball hit her belly hard and she fell back, slamming her head against the floor. A whistle sounded. The coach sprinted onto the court. "Sheila, go get the nurse!" She cradled the girl's head. "Cara, are you all right?"

He couldn't believe his luck. He slithered into the locker room and made his way to the bomb sitting secretly at the bottom of his locker.
14131.title: What a punch!

choices: Invisible shmisible
141311.content:
Okay, this was it! He pulled open his locker door and smiled devilishly. He bent down, squeezed the scissors in his hand, and cut the little green wire. A clock started to count down.

"In just about three minutes, this whole place is gonna blow up," Skander heard. Immediately, he shook out the shock in his hand, and turned around. His feet pounded against the upstairs floor. His heart raced, he opened his mouth, and started to scream.

Mrs. Woods stood from her desk. "What in the world is that noise?" She walked towards the door, "stay here," she told her students. But before she could open the door, Skander pushed it so hard it almost slammed into her forehead.

"GET OUT!" he shouted. The students panicked.

"What is wrong with him?" One girl asked her friend.

"GET OUT, NOW! THERE'S A BOMB IN THE SCHOOL!"

Everyone scurried from the room. They ran down the stairs and outside of the building, through the parking lot, until they reached the softball field. Other students from other classes followed them. A herd of cattle, they made their way outside.

The boy hurried from the locker room and ran into a frantic mob of people. He knew what was happening, but he didn't care. Not everyone could escape, not in this crowd. He had trouble finding a way out, but he made it. He ran to outdoor track, sat on the hot asphalt, and waited.

"GET OUT! EVERYONE GET OUT! THERE'S A BOMB!" One by one, the class doors opened and people ran to freedom and safety. When he was sure everyone had heard him, he hurried downstairs and outside. Then he noticed the boy.

About a football field away from the school, the students and faculty stood, waiting. They didn't know if it would reach them. The uncertainty was unbearable. They huddled like a huge football team. They were on the farthest part of the softball field, where the bases were about a hundred feet away from them. A fence enclosed them in. They were as close as they could come to the edge of the land--where it stopped and the ground fell around the huge trees--and almost hugging the holes of the metal fence.

"I want to know one thing," Skander said. He couldn't believe his bravery at this moment. This guy had tried to kill everyone, but he was saving them. Skander, of all people! He was the one they had ignored on a daily basis, but now he was their hero. "Why would you want to murder innocent people?"

The boy stood. "They're not innocent. They're evil. I'd laugh at seeing the face blown off of a fifteen year old girl. You're blocking the view. I can't wait to see this!"

"You're disgusting."

The boy lifted his arm to punch him, but Skander grabbed a hold of him. He twisted the boy's arm back and listened to his high-pitched wail. "Let me go!"

"Why? So you can try to kill off another nine hundred people?" He heard sirens in the distance. Someone had called the police.

The boy wriggled free when Skander tried to hear if the police were coming closer to them. He socked Skander in the eye, kicked him between the legs, and watched him writhe in pain on the ground.

But Skander wasn't done. He grabbed the boy's foot before he could shove it into Skander's side. He flipped him over and the boy's face hit the pavement. Skander got up to dust himself off.

Then it happened. The noise almost knocked him down. Flames licked the sky and ashes sprinkled the ground. The school he'd known, the school his parents had attended, was dead. The boy quietly crept up behind him. He wrapped his spaghetti arms around Skander's neck. From his left pocket, he pulled out a gun. "Look at it, ain't it beautiful?" Skander tried to push the boy away. "Not so brave now, are you, big shot? Do that again and I'll put a bullet in your head."

This was not the way it was supposed to happen. Skander was a simple boy, possibly an alien with supernatural powers. No one was supposed to get killed. No one was supposed to be hurt. But with every hero there is a villain, and with every story there is an end. Skander was listening to the boy's uneven thoughts, and the sound of fire trucks and police cars and ambulances. He closed his eyes and prepared himself. But what he thought was his pounding heart was actually the hurried steps of a police officer. "Put it down! Now! Put the gun down!" The man drew his own gun and aimed it at the boy.

"Oh god," the boy thought. He dropped his gun and Skander let the officer rip him away from the boy.

The officer put away his gun, wrestled the boy to the ground, and slapped handcuffs onto his wrists.

He looked up at Skander, standing like the small and weak boy he always were, but with a power so strong that if he wanted to, he could take a bullet and sustain his life. "You did good, kid," the officer said. He pulled the boy to his feet and walked to the police car, dragging the villain away.

Skander decided to go home and rest for a while. It was tiring being a superhero. He thought it was all over, but when he started to walk home, he discovered not only did he hear thoughts and have super strength. His hands rose to his face, but he did not see them. Oh, Skander thought, a little less scared of this one: he could become invisible too.
141311.title: The showdown

choices: Talk to them or make yourself known another way
Try to reverse your invisibility first
1413111.content:
After everything that had happened today, Skander just sighed wearily at this new revelation. He really didn't know how to deal with this. In just one day, his whole life had been turned upside-down.
This morning his only worry had been about being late to school and now...now had to deal with all those strange new abilities. Not to mention the fact that the whole school by now probably only consisted of smoking ruins and ash.
Skander was beyond glad that nobody had gotten hurt, even though he couldn't help but wonder if he could have prevented the boy from setting off the bomb in the first place.
He should have talked to him first. He should have tried to find out what would cause someone to attempt to murder so many innocent people.
Skander shook his head and ran a hand through his hair. Getting all worked up would do no good.
Looking down to where his feet were supposed to be, he noted with rising panic that he was still invisible. His eyes widened and his breath grew faster as he realized that he had absolutely no idea how to control his powers.
He couldn't imagine living with these voices in his head for his whole life and what if he accidentally injured someone with his super-strenght?
And he definitely couldn't stay invisible his whole life.
First things first. He needed to get home and tell his parents that he was okay. They were bound to be worried after what happened. He just needed to find a way to tell them that he was invisible without shocking them too much.
Skander hurried down the streets, trying hard to ignore the thoughts of the people passing him.

He unlocked the door as quietly as possible, hoping his parents wouldn't notice anything. A door opening by itself might not be the best way to greet them.
Skander put down his bag and hesitantly made his way into the living room.
His parents were sitting huddled together on the couch, their eyes fixed intently on the TV. Just as Skander had expected, the news were filled with reports about the bomb. He was relieved to see that they didn't mention him. He had enough to deal with without the added pressure of appearing on TV.
"God, I hope he's okay."
Skander looked at his mother, who had buried her face in her husband's neck and seemed to hold back her tears.
His father was stroking her back soothingly in a circular pattern, while murmuring reassuring words in her ear.
Skander felt guilty for making them worry so much and wondered what he should do now. He couldn't just start talking, could he?
A voice from out of nowhere would surely freak them out. Maybe he should try to reverse his invisibility before doing anything else, even though he had no idea if it was going to work.

4-6: More advanced physical powers (Contortion, elastication, invisibility, higher levels of the previous level ect)

30: Near unlimited power (Note there is only one creature who is a level thirty and there can't be another)
[Note: colour of energy blasts determine the level, yellow is 7 (normally), green is 8, blue is 9-14 (normally), pink is 15-21, dark red is 22-27 and bright red is 28-30]

143.content:
Skander sat at his desk, he was writing a story, his pen scraped across the page as he jotted down an exciting fight scene. It was completely dark in his room apart from the lamp on his desk, which cast a slightly yellow hue over everything.

"Interesting story."
"Thanks," Skander said. He kept writing.
"You know that 'San Franksico' doesn't have a 'K' in it, right?"
"Huh? Oh..." Skander said, and crossed out the bay city and re-wrote it correctly. "Thank...wait a minute! Who said that!?"

He put his pen down and turned around in his chair. There was no-one there. Then he heard someone whistling. He looked up to see someone sitting top of his bookcase! The figure jumped off and floated down towards the ground.

"Wha...woah!" Skander spluttered, "Who are you!?"

The ghost floated towards him, "I'm Master Adrian. Master Adrian Jeremiah Stone. And you, Skander Kenneth Jones, have about as much a command of the English language as a Chinaman."

"Who are you?" Skander said.
"I'm a ghost," said the boy.

Skander stared at Master Adrian. He looked a little older than Skander, and was about the same height. He wore a sharp, black three-piece suit and a black fedora hat. A glistening gold double-albert watch-chain stretched from one pocket of his waistcoat through the central buttonhole to the other pocket. His shoes were shiny black leather. He looked like a perfectly dressed young man. Except that everything was slightly transparent and dead.

"I've been watching you ever since you first moved into my house," said the ghost, pacing, "I think I like you."
"I'm talking to a GHOST?" Skander asked.
"Sure, why not?" the ghost replied, "What's the matter? Ain't all jazzed up about talkin' to a spiiirrriiit?" he asked.
"I...I never knew I could talk to ghosts," said Skander.

Master Adrian shrugged, "Yeah, whatever. Well you are now, Skandy-boy." the ghost laughed. "What's the matter? You look like you seen a ghost...oh wait! YOU HAVE!" and he laughed at his own joke. "Relax, kid, I'm not here to hurt you."

"W-well that's a relief...ah...nice to meet you...uh...Master Adrian."
"Oh scrap the formalities..." Adrian said, "Just call me Adrian."
"O-okay," said Skander. "So um...when did you die?"
"Fourth of January, 1919. In the middle of an epidemic of Spanish Influenza," the boy said. "Thats...what? 90 years ago now? Wow. Yep, I've been dead a loooong time. And this was my house. And this was my room. But I still think it's my house and I still think this is my room. I'm never gonna leave this place because I don't want to. Now that you can see me and talk to me, let's get that one thing straight. I'm here to stay whether you like it or not."

"Hey buddy," said Skander, "I...I don't want any trouble..."
"Good," said Adrian, "I don't want to give any."
"We...w-want to be friends?" Skander asked. Truth to be told, having a ghost for a friend was a pretty cool idea.
"Sure," said the ghost. "Nice to meet you."

Skander watched Adrian pull out a semi-transparent gold pocket watch from his waistcoat. He checked the time on it and then pocketed it.

"That looks like a pretty expensive watch..." Skander said.
"It was my father's," Adrian replied, "He gave it to me when I got the Influenza. I had wanted it my entire life. Well, now I can keep it my entire AFTERlife!" he chuckled. He pulled ghostly silver case from his coat and opened it. He pulled out a cigarette and put it between his lips. He lit the cigarette with a match from a pocket match-safe.

"Isn't that supposed to be bad for your health?" Skander asked.
"I've been dead ninety years," Adrian said, "What health?"
"Right," Skander nodded.
143.title: "I See Dead People".

choices: At lunchtime, Jason sees Adrian 'in the flesh' for the first time.
Skander tries moving things without his hands. He has telekinesis!
Skander can see more ghosts in the classroom than just Adrian!
1431.content:
"Hmmmm..."

"Wakey-wakey..."

"Muuuuhhh..."

"Eggs and bakey..."

"Huuuuugh....hmmm..."

"GET UP!"

"WOAH JESUS!"

Skander jumped up, hitting his head on his bedside lamp and cursing very creatively. Adrian laughed, "you should've seen your face! Come on, get up, it's time for school. I've seen you wake up late nearly every day this week! Wouldn't hpapen in my day. We'd get our asses caned so bad we'd be standing up for a whole week! Now move it!"

"Thanks for the wake-up call, Adrian..." Skander said. He started changing, tugging on a T-shirt, a jacket and jeans, socks and sneakers. He packed his bag and headed into the kitchen. Plenty of time. Perhaps having a ghost in the house was gonna be a good thing. Skander sat down at the breakfast table where his mother put a plate of bacon and eggs in front of him.

"Oooh that does look good," said Adrian, "I haven't had bacon and eggs in ninety years...Enjoy!"
"Yeah yeah, stop bothering me!" Skander said, "I want to eat!"

"Sorry, did you say something honey?" Mrs. Jones asked, who was preparing her own breakfast.

"Uh, n-nothing mah!" Skander said. "Just um..."
"Oh Adrian!"

Skander looked up. What?

Adrian was floating above the stove, watching the eggs and bacon frying.

"You can talk to ghosts too?" Skander asked.
"Oh sure," said Mrs. Jones, "I wondered how I was going to introduce Adrian to you, but I think you two already met. I think there's a clairvoyant or psychic streak in our family."

"A...what?" Skander asked.
"We can speak to the dead," said Mrs. Jones, sitting down.
"Hey!" Adrian shouted.
"Sorry dear," Mrs. Jones added.

After breakfast, Skander and Adrian walked to school, the ghost floating along beside Skander. He was early enough today that he could walk to school instead of taking the bus. They headed into class and sat down at one of the desks at the back. Jason wasn't there yet. It was double history.

"...Okay boys, take out your books," said Mr. Anderson, walking in, "We're continuing our lesson on World War One, known before 1945 as the Great War. This was the first modern war...Mr. Lancet, you're late."
"Sorry sir," said Jason. He headed down the back and sat next to Skander and pulled out his books.

"...with aircraft, tanks and chemical warfare..."

"Do you feel something?" Jason asked.
"Huh?" Skander replied, "What?"
"I feel cold..."
"Oh...No, I'm fine."

Jason tried to write down his notes. Skander watched him. Then he saw the zip on Jason's pencil-case open of its own accord. A biro floated out.

"Adrian!" Skander whispered, "What are you doing?"

The biro continued to float in mid-air, rotating slowly.

"I never got these newfangled...ball-point pens..." Adrian whispered, "They're so hard to use...I prefer fountain pens..." He put the pen down on Jason's desk and picked up a calculator. "In my day we used BRAINS..."

"Stop it! Someone'll see you..." Skander whispered.
"Who's your friend?" Adrian asked.
"Jason..."
"Cool, I'm gonna meet him."
"Don't!..."
"Hey, I'm a ghost and you're a mortal, you can't touch me, skin-tube."

The biro lifted off the desk and started writing on a blank page in Jason's notebook. The writing was loopy and old-fashioned.

"Hello, Jason." it read.

"Hey Skand..." Jason said, "I didn't know you wrote this neat..."
"It's not me..." Skander whispered.

"...My name is Adrian..." the pen wrote. Then Jason stared at it. "What the!?" he spluttered.
"Don't be afraid...Skander knows me very well. I just want to meet you..."

Jason looked at Skander, whose two hands were on his own desk.

"No way...what..."

"...I'm a ghost...Boo!"

Skander had to grin at this. The pen dropped flat on the desk and didn't move.

"No way..." Jason whispered. "Really?"

Skander nodded. "Let's just say we bumped into each other at home..."
1431.title: Adrian, Jason. Jason, Adrian. Shake hands.

choices: Skander gets angry at the fighting. His eyes glow red. Heat-rays!

14311.content:
"We're all alone,
No chaperone,
Can get our number,
The world's in slumber,

Let's misbehave!

There's somethin' wild,
About you, child,
That's so contagious!
Let's be outrageous!
Let's misbehave!

When Adam took Eve's hand,

"What the hell is that?" Skander shouted as he approached Adrian in a secluded corner of the school. The ghost was leaning against a wall, smoking a cigarette.

Jason jogged over. "This is too freaky..." he said, "A GHOST?"

"Uh...hi," said Jason. It felt weird shaking hands with a ghost.

"So do you have any weird powers?" Jason asked.

143111.content:
Skander started panting heavily. He hated it when people fought, although he couldn't entirely blame Adrian for getting so angry, Jason could be so bloody THICK sometimes.

"Guuugh! STOP IT!" Skander shouted. His eyes flashed red and something akin to a laser shot out of them, hitting the bench whch Jason was standing next to. It burst into flames!

"JESUS!" Jason screamed and jumped aside. Adrian whirled around.

"What the!?" the ghost spluttered out. Clenching his teeth, the ghost blew, hard! The sudden gust of wind blew the fire on the bench out. He looked quickly at Skander, who was looking at Jason, who was also looking at Skander.

"What the HELL was that!?" Jason shouted.
"I told you he wasn't normal," said Adrian, "See?"
"I...I don't know..." Skander spluttered, "I just got so angry and..."

"Your eyes turned red", Adrian added.
"Huh?" Jason asked.
"I saw it..." said Adrian, suddenly, "Out of the corner of my eye...A red glint...I think you have heat-rays or something in your eyes!"

"WHAT?" Skander shouted, "That's impossible!"

Adrian swirled over to where Skander was standing. He snapped his fingers. A crumpled up burger-wrapper hovered out of the bin and floated over to between the boys.

"Set it on fire, it's paper, it should burn," said Adrian.
"But..."
"DO IT!"

Nervously, Skander looked at the crumpled ball of paper.

"Burn," he said, unenthusiastically.
"You have to MEAN IT!" Adrian shouted.
"BURN!" Skander roared. Suddenly, his eyes turned blood red! A red laser-light shot out of them, striking the hovering piece of paper, setting it on fire!

"Woah, cool!" Jason said. Adrian let the ball of charred paper fall to the ground. "It is something...rather extraordinary," he said. He tugged his pocket watch from his waistcoat, "We still have..." he looked at the dial, "Forty minutes...until the end of lunch," he put his watch back into his waistcoat pocket, "Why don't we see what else our friend can do, hmm Jason?"

"W-why not?" Jason said, stammering from amazement.
143111.title: Great Balls of Fire!

choices: Adrian and Jason search for more things for Skander to 'target-pratice' on.
Skander discovers another power!
1431111.content:
Turning back towards the school-buildings, the boys headed off to find an empty classroom. Adrian walked next to Skander and Jason next to Adrian. Adrian was completely solid now, or he appeared completely solid, at least. Anybody looking at him would think he was just another guy. Except that he was wearing a suit that hadn't been seen in shopfront windows in about a hundred years. If anyone actually bothered looking really close, they would've noticed that Adrian was not even walking on the GROUND. He actually hovered up above it about an inch or two.

Skander reached a classroom and peered in through the small window. It was deserted, and in a quiet part of the school. He tried the handle. It was locked.

"Huh!" Adrian said, "Locked doors...Leave this to me."

As casually as if he was stepping into a shower to wash himself up, the ghost-teen stepped through the door. There was a moment's silence, and then...

Click!

The lock turned and the door opened.

"Come in, gentlemen," he said.
"Neat!" said Jason, staring at Adrian with a new respect. Adrian slammed the door shut behind them.

"Now, let's see what else you can do, Skander," said Adrian, hovering in mid-air near the ceiling.

Feeling stupid, Skander ran, jogged, jumped, waved his arms, blinked, coughed, blew...so far, the only thing he could do was shoot fire-lasers from his eyes and set things on fire. He sat, dejected, on a chair at the back of the room, thinking. He flicked his hands, rapidly clenching and unclenching his fingers in quick, snappish movements.

"Come on, I have to be able to do SOMETHING!" he said. He threw out his right hand and extended his fingers, as if he was releasing an imaginary yo-yo.

WHAM!

Something very bright and a mix between white and sky-blue, shot out of his hands! It hit a desk and blew it to pieces, the force of the blast sending two chairs flying across the room!

"I think...we found a new power," said Adrian, recovering from the shock and hovering back down towards earth.
"What was that!?" he asked.
"I...I think...No! It can't be...that stuff isn't real..."
"What's he talking about?" Adrian asked, looking at Jason.
"No idea," Jason said.
"Pulse beams!" Skander said, "I can shoot balls of energy out of my hands...or electricity or...something!"

"Hmmm..." Adrian said. He hovered over to the rubbish-bin in the corner and fished through it. He pulled out a torn maths-book.

"FIRE!" he shouted. He threw it into the air. Skander extended his arms and fingers in the same, quick, snappish motion.

WHAM!

Two balls of bright light shot through the air, hitting the book squarely in the cover, blasting it apart! Pages fluttered to the ground. Jason went to pick them up, the pages were torn to pieces, but also slightly singed, as if something very hot had hit them and then disappeared again very quickly.

"This is COOL!" he said.

Skander has more fun with his super strength.
143112.content:
Since they still had about ten minutes in their lunch hour, Skander, Adrian and Jason wandered around the woods behind the school. There were a lot of tall trees, and since it had rained a lot recently, lots of branches had fallen on the ground as well.

Suddenly, Skander stopped in his tracks and was overcome by a serious stiffness in every muscle in his body.

“Oh man… I feel so stiff right now…” he said, as every muscle tensed up.

“Whoa! What’s happening to him?” Jason wondered, as he noted something weird about Skander.

Skander appeared to be getting… bigger? His chest started to push out, and his sweater was suddenly fitting very tight. His arms became thicker, as his biceps inflated dramatically. His torso widened at the shoulders, to the point where he began to resemble a teen bodybuilder. Skander looked like he was about to burst out of his clothes, but the growth stopped short of that.

“Uhhhh…” he groaned, as he flexed his arms. “Ooooh God… I-I’m getting stronger or something…”

“Well, the chicks are gonna notice for sure!” Adrian grinned, as he folded his arms and just stared at Skander while he was having his growth spurt.

Next, his legs thickened and widened at the same time, filling out his jeans. His calves inflated, making his jeans fit super-tight around his new, bulging muscles!

“Ugh… I need to buy bigger clothes!” Skander groaned.

“Wow! Look at him! He just grew all that muscle in a matter of seconds!” Jason exclaimed.

Skander then walked over to pick up a huge, 10-inch-thick tree branch, which was laying on the ground. He easily lifted it up, and then he rested it on his thigh before snapping the thick branch in half like it was a toothpick.

“Great Scot! You’re strong!” Adrian shouted.

“I-I guess I discovered super strength…” Skander grinned, as he tossed the huge branch on the floor like it was nothing.

The boys then started walking back to class, since they were almost out of time.
